posts.name: Maddy Fahey
posts.cooked: A little while back, our team had a joke discussion on the effectiveness of certain semi-absurd methods of defending against trench shooters in Infinite Recharge. The strongest contenders were a “No-Board” (to physically block a power cell) and a fan (to alter the path of the cell). But the question has been gnawing at me ever since: I mean, hey, WOULD it work? How strong would the fan have to be to mess with a cell’s trajectory enough to knock it away from the high port? Is that even legal? I’m quite eager to hear other people entertain the idea.

I don’t know the equation for it, but I’m pretty sure the air the fan is pushing dissipates pretty quickly into the surrounding air meaning the pushing force on the cell will get much less as you move away from it. You could counter this with a funnel or ducts around the fan but the principle should still hold.

On the other hand, something like a leafblower seems strong enough to push a powercell and even small disturbances in the trajectory could mean the cell hits a corner and doesn’t enter the scoring area.

Fun idea.

posts.name: David Birch
posts.cooked: I remember people trying that in 2013 against frisbees, however I don’t recall it being very effective

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: We experimented with using a fan for defense in 2013. We went as far as designing a 2 CIM powered wind machine. What we found was the ball/frisbee was being shot so fast that it only stayed in the fan’s air stream for milliseconds. Even when shooting frisbees across the whole field, it just didn’t make any appreciable difference.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked: Specifically in 2009, team overdrive, 2753, one of the only rookie teams to make it to Einstein, utilized a fan to help their acceleration on the low friction surface, which helped immensely. The fan also prevented some cells from from going into the trailers.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: You could just squeeze a 30" ducted fan inside the (202x) frame perimeter.  Position that exhaust-end up near the height limit and power it with as many motors as possible before exceeding the current limits.   Pretty sure that would blow most any power cell crossing over that ~28" column of air well off target.
Can confirm it was very effective, also against cycling robots as well. It’s my favorite 869 / 747 robot, though 2019 had more competition success.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Here’s some history tidbits for ya.

Back in the first actual shooting game, in 2006, several teams decided that this was A Thing To Try. Back then there was a velocity limit, and folks tried with leafblowers and the like. Nobody succeeded, that year.

To work you need a slow projectile and a tiny target.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
This picture looks like a scene from a Final Destination movie. Propeller pushes the cart, knocking over propane tank, propeller loses balance, flies off and hits the valve on the tank, releasing propane gas, battery falls off the cart, sparks on the cart handle on the way down igniting the propane.

Okay, maybe a bit far fetched.

Fun fact, the movie Return to Horror High features a scene with a propeller on a test stand that goes awry. The scene was filmed in what is now 696’s lab.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
It’s a bit hard to make out, but here is some match video from Overdrive, 2753 (RIP) who installed a fan on their bot after their first event because they had the space. One of the most simple and effective robots, possibly of all time.

The original bot:

https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/4/a/4aef53b56b70aa94516025f04b0c8494d0fb7423.jpeg

Several others had fans in 2009 as well, but I don’t ever recall the fans preventing someone from scoring the moon rocks. 1771 and I believe 45 come to mind as others. 1771 was by far my favorite one from that season.

And fwiw 869 was quite effective in 2013. Enough so they were selected for their defensive capabilities. @anon24941552 can shed more light.

Akash_Rastogi:

And fwiw 869 was quite effective in 2013. Enough so they were selected for their defensive capabilities. @anon24941552 can shed more light.

When I was mentoring FRC11 we played a bunch with 869’s fan robot, once declining the 1st seed and picking 869 from 4th seed. I think a lot of people in this thread are underestimating how good the fan mechanism was.

In the “windsock” configuration it was difficult for short cycling robots to score without shooting into the sock and having their frisbees fall to the floor. In the “sockless” configuration, it would play mind games with full court shooters. Every FCS robot needed a few throwaway frisbees to dial in their shots, and without the windsock, it was very hard to tell if the fan was blowing or not. 869 was able to turn the fan on/off as their opponents were dialing in, making them unsure if they actually needed to adjust their shot higher or lower.

The robot/fan mechanism was GOOD in teleop. The only reason the robot didn’t go further was it lacked the ability to shoot frisbees in autonomous mode. It would go blow for blow in teleop/endgame value with the best cyclers out there, it just started the match in a points hole without an autonomous mode.

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Mark_Wasserman:

Safety third!

Mark, please tell me you did not wind that prop up to rated speed with humans nearby!

I’m guessing that rated thrust would be much higher than ten pounds, so maybe the speed was limited by available power from the Falcon?  Even so, that motor might get tip speed well past 200 MPH.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
That pic is from when me and Jerry did Beta testing on the Falcon in his personal shop so if you count me and Jerry as humans then we were nearby.  It doesn’t alarm me much since I’ve been standing in front of giant scale RC airplanes hand starting them since age 11 so at least I have an appreciation for their danger (and the scars to prove it).

I believe that prop is normally driven by a 4-5hp chainsaw motor @ 6000+RPM producing about 30lbs of thrust.  The Falcon could spin it around 1800 RPM which was limited by the 40A breaker (81A @ 6V).  It was the easiest way to produce a constant load to do temperature testing.

If the tips don’t break the speed of sound, you’re good.
